comments.commentBody:
You opinion is perfectly ok but my experience has been different. I have had 5-6 female bosses, and 4-5 male bosses.

Overall women communicate better, are more considerate, and tend to play fewer games. I sort of agree that women are more about teamwork and less about cynical team sabotage.

Men are often a little more ambitious -- for themselves. Given the choice, I prefer working for women. But honestly, despite the problems I have seen both genders behave mostly very effectively together. Making it a gender war is unhelpful - and making it a sexual dynamic is also unhelpful. Work is work.
Colleges have no choice under current law but to investigate students' allegations of sexual abuse. This does not constitute"usurpation" of criminal investigation, which can proceed independently.

I am a college professor and former dean in the University of California. I can confidentially assert that no other serious disciplinary cases on campus are resolved on a mere preponderance of evidence basis. For example, if I knew that one of two students stole the answers to an exam and distributed them to classmates, and I was 51% sure that Student A stole the exam and 49% sure it was Student B, there is no way that Student A would be expelled or punished. We simply would not consider that strong enough evidence to take action.

While preventing and punishing sexual assault should be a very high priority for campuses, to make serious disciplinary decisions of any kind based on a narrow preponderance of evidence is not wise. It means that in potentially up to half the cases, you will be unjustly punishing a student. And in the cases of sexual assault, an unjust expulsion would likely be accompanied by an unjust social media campaign against the student, with potentially disastrous life consequences.

I'm confused: If you are not using "a preponderance of the evidence" standard, then what standard are you using?

For example, if you are using a "clear and convincing" or "beyond a reasonable doubt" standard for all purported violations of the code (or whatever it is called on campus), then no students in your hypothetical would be responsible. But if you are using a preponderance of the evidence standard, then the student that the board determines is 51% responsible for the theft IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE THEFT and should get the appropriate punishment (another conversation entirely) and the student who is 49% responsible should not receive any punishment.

The point: You can't pick and choose what kind of standard you are going to use and then apply that standard--or a fuzzy-headed version--differently as to peculiar facts, and according to the whims of the members of the board (i.e., "We simply would not consider that strong enough evidence to take action").

Huh?

The fact that MW is a college professor and former dean is an example of what makes a lot of us very nervous (I'm a corporate litigator) as to how these disciplinary cases pan out.

If you are not using a preponderance of evidence standard to sort out a garden-variety college "cheating" case, including the hypo you describe which may not be garden-variety because it involves two students, only one of which can apparently be solely responsible for the theft and distribution, then

Great questions. Unlike George, I have never received specific instructions as to what standards of evidence should be used. Rather, as an Associate Dean and an Interim Dean, I was involved in many specific cases related to inappropriate behavior of students. It was made clear to me by campus administration in these cases that we needed very strong evidence to proceed with serious disciplinary measures. Though the specific level of evidence we needed was not named (at least in my recollection), I would associate it with the term "clear and convincing."

This sub-thread is yet another example of how inherently flawed campus disciplinary boards are when it comes to fairness and consistency, across years and across cases -- and it's not the faculty-members' or students' fault, assuming they make up the board. They are often being asked to do very complicated things with little to no training.

Many people here and in the larger thread are conflating what we use in the civil lawsuit context as liability vs. damages (or in the criminal context: conviction vs. sentencing). A student is either liable (or responsible, to use a kinder term) for a rule violation or not. But what is the burden / standard of proof for liability / responsibility? As to damages (i.e., punishment), that conversation sometimes takes on a life of its own (unless spelled out in the code, such as if you are responsible for X, then you automatically get Y punishment), and may, as someone pointed out, require a higher burden of proof (say, "clear and convincing" evidence) to effectuate a more draconian punishment. Like expulsion.

Do hardworking well-meaning people on the board actually know (1) the code, (2) burdens of proof and how to apply them to complicated fact-patterns, (3) the difference between responsibility and punishment, (4) how any ultimate decision, from majority to unanimity, implicates very complex ideas about social justice and community?

This stuff is hard enough to do with a good judge and a competent jury, and a life's training.

Good to know that a large enough number of people read the NYT enough to be passionate, organized and focused to call their Congressional representatives and be successful at evoking shame in the ranks of those who would gut a process of ethics watchdogging that is producing results.  At last!
Trump cleaves "us" from "them". That is enough for many.

It's all a stage presence, a "persona" - while you're snickering about his grammar, he is becoming your master.

This act has been highly effective for him - if that's not smart, I don't know what is - certainly, not what Mrs. C. was doing during the campaign.

Even one term will do massive damage. If you don't want to live with him for a second term, you better go out and start organizing now - and don't worry about the grammar of the people you speak to.
Getting sicker after a period of access to healthcare might just be what it takes to get working-class conservatives to actually vote their interest.

Speaker Ryan appears to feel the same way. He'll "revisit" the "issue" at a later date, perhaps while our backs are turned and the spotlights are off.

It's not the principle, it's the "optics," as the asinine term today has it.

President Obama took us from nearly 10 percent unemployment to well below 5 percent. No jobs created? Do you consider that "fake news"?

In contrast, DT has routinely destroyed jobs and small contractors by stiffing ordinary workers and small businesses. He couldn't even run a casino at a profit. I'm not sure we need more of that "experience."

These Republican "lawmakers" are idiots. For decades they've had no plans for health care, no thought to helping with educational opportunity, they've dumbed down the education system, created a landscape with a gun on every street corner waiting to kill an innocent victim, and they have relied on a failed trickle-down economic ideology that has produced the largest wealth inequality in world history.

So what's the first thing they do?...they try to pass measures in secret that would allow them to potentially carry out unethical, and even criminal, acts to benefit themselves.

The GOP has forgotten how to govern and, even worse, has lost the desire to do so. Politics has become nothing more than a 3D version of poker in which they gamble the future of our nation away and give the remains to a foreign power..."move on"...one car wreck after another, but they tell us there's nothing to see.

In my opinion, Title IX is important and does not contradict the justice system at all. When you think of a college institution as a kind of company or industry (you pay money, tuition; they offer a service, education), then it makes sense. Every employee handbook that I've read has a section asserting that disrespect, harassment or discrimination in the workplace can lead to termination and/or severe consequences. The same goes for colleges and universities. Harassment and discrimination (which makes up the foundation of Title IX) should lead to some form of review process to see whether or not the respondent ("accused," if you will) deserves to stay in that particular institution.
Subsequently, if the reporting party chooses to press criminal charges before, during or after the review process at the university, then they can do that as well. Sexual assault can result in trauma, fear and even feelings of humiliation and isolation that make it difficult to process the incident. Thus, they might avoid calling local police.
For this reason, I don't see the university system as a replacement of the justice system at all. I see it as a process, one that is adopted by most American institutions anyways, to review the incident and make a decision based on the evidence provided. Essentially, it serves to determine whether or not an individual violated the "company rules" and what sanctions should be given out, whether that means remedial therapy, suspension or expulsion.

You make a good point, but colleges differ from most companies in that students live as well as 'work' there. So their entire lives, social and personal as well as academic, are potentially under college authority. Few alleged sexual assaults occur in classrooms during 'work' hours. Using your company analogy, if employee A accuses employee B of raping her after a date on Saturday night, outside of work hours and away from the workplace, is that a matter for the company's internal discipline? Sincere question--I don't know the answer.

One might analogize colleges to workplaces, like a ship or oil rig, where employees live as well as work. But what about sexual assaults between students alleged to occur at off-campus housing? My intuition is with those who say these are criminal matters, for police and courts. You point out why it may not be that simple, but I don't think it is simple your way either.

Fair point. No judicial case is simple. Even civil cases are complicated, so it is fair to say that there is no perfect way to adjudicate sexual assault without running into obstacles. I think the issue at hand is that today you don't just go to college to take classes. Greek life, for example, extends far beyond taking classes. Same goes with extracurricular activities. Yet those activities are sponsored and funded by the college so I guess it does actually count as "work hours."

The off-campus situation is a tricky one. Generally the campus police is called first at those locations if the incident is reported immediately. This allows the student to get a PERK kit done right away as well, which provides incontrovertible evidence that a rape occurred. The police then have to follow through with a criminal investigation if the reporting party wishes to press charges. Most people don't right away.

Once that investigation is done, then the school investigation begins and they decide whether or not they want the respondent on their campus. This is from my understanding as a college student myself.
Republicans in Congress are worried about ethical oversight - not a good sign for the future. Here's a novel idea, Congress: Don't do bad stuff, then you won't have to worry about oversight.

Enough. Can we please face facts? Trump is crazy. Literally. His personality disorder is, at best, semi-amusing when associated with a whack job we may encounter at work or in the neighborhood. But this man is about to become president. He sits in his 5th Avenue aerie surrounded by sycophants and tweeting nonsense, completely detached from reality and putting the security of the nation at risk. You, NYT, and the rest of the media are facing the biggest challenge in American history. Please, please take this man down.

I've said this before:
Bipolar with Borderline Personality- added to Narcissistic Personality.. multiple diagnosis? I
This was a bizarre read and should not have been published.

Trump's tweets are nauseating, like practically all his public utterances. We might have to endure much worse - his speeches, let alone his policies. This being said, Chinese and Russian diplomacy is nothing to brag about. It often expresses itself in even shorter form: their vetoes at the UN Security Council which are responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths, from Darfour, to the Balkans, to Syria. We can only hope that Trump's tweets don't unleash a similar legacy.

Love your last paragraph!

Witty!

@ saizwho
Republicans have led a very effective campaign against Obamacare, aided and abetted by Fox and right wing radio. There are polls that give the ACA high marks when it is called the ACA rather than Obamacare and some of the components of the law are very popular such as the coverage for children until they are 26 and prohibiting insurance companies from denying coverage for pre-existing conditions.
It is anybody's guess what they will replace it with, for 7 years they have been trying to repeal it with no alternative plan, like Chuck Schumer said, "the dog has caught the bus".
I am an ER physician and I think the ACA has helped many that would have used the ER to obtain their primary care, a bad idea but was very common before the ACA, less so now. ER's are expensive and there is no continuity of care so to speak.
I understand your worries and I feel for you but you can take heart in the fact that your benefits may extend for 2 years, they won't do anything to upset you before the midterm election.
If you want an explanation of Republican logic, read Dickens.

Should we care what the Chinese communists advise us about running a democracy? More fake news--exaggerated importance and siding with our competitors. Reporters are afraid that they're being cut out of Trump''s relationshipeith the people.

China is right about the tweeting.  Trumps' tweets are demeaning, rude, sarcastic, rambling, ambiguous. We may understand the nuance of his tweets but will other nations? Remember the misunderstandings and threat of nuclear war with Russia when John F Kennedy was in office. Russia had missles in Cuba aimed at us.  This is serious President Elect Trump. Get off your golden seat and do some real work, starting with proper grammar and full sentences. I can't believe I'm asking the next President of the United States to use proper English when it comes to diplomacy between nations.
Please note, all immigrants, and only immigrants, are required to demonstrate an adequate grasp of spoken and written English as part of their Naturalization process to become citizens.

Trump went to Wharton undergrad which is harder to get into than Harvard.  Regardless, predicting draconian outcomes while comparing irrelevant pedigree to assert nonsensical points seem to be what the NYT favors these days.

I am mystified that there are no national security rules or guidelines that actually forbid federal officials, including the president, from using social media e.g tweets to engage foreign powers on matters of national import. What I had always held to be strict rules of behavior and engagement at the presidential level have turned out to be only conventions followed by the serious and well-informed but completely disregarded by Trump. Some serious rethinking of the rules and how to force adherence is in order or we are in big trouble.

The latest news, courtesy of the Wall Street Journal, is that Emperor Donald wants to reform and cut back the intelligence agencies.

This is classic dictator practice:

Gain power.

Limit the press.

Limit the intelligence services.

Compromise national security.

Emperor Donald sounds like a DICTATOR in the making.

Even Evan McMullen, who ran as a third party Presidential candidate, and is a former CIA operative, thinks the same thing.

The time for true American patriots, of whatever political persuasion, to stand up to this buffoon would-be dictator is NOW.

We live in interesting times.
Will world leaders one at a time or in droves start to laugh out loud at the tweeter n chief.

"Don't Tweet Me Bad"

- Xi Jinping

Come on China, you should be smart enough to manipulate this er bai wu!! It's an easy three step process...

1) Have Mr. Xi exclaim how brilliant Trump is. Make sure to post it prominently and off.

2) Apologize to the American people (you don't have to mean it) for causing such hardship by taking jobs from the USA.

3) Let it be known far and wide that you want to make amends to the American people by purchasing some American companies and hiring more US workers. For every worker you actually hire claim three and give all credit to Trump.

This simple effort will have Trump eating out of China's hands. Try it!!
